animalOfTheDay.name: trout
facts: Some trout species migrate between freshwater and saltwater during their life cycle.
They are indicators of clean water and are sensitive to pollution.
They can detect vibrations in the water through their lateral line system.
Trout have excellent vision and can see in color.

calendar.name: tarsier
facts: They communicate using ultrasonic frequencies beyond human hearing.
Tarsiers have the largest eyes relative to body size of any mammal.
They can rotate their heads nearly 180 degrees in each direction.
Tarsiers are the only entirely carnivorous primates, eating insects, lizards, and small birds.

calendar.name: tasmanian devil
facts: Tasmanian devils are carnivorous marsupials native to Tasmania, Australia.
They are known for their ferocious screeches and powerful bite.
Tasmanian devils are solitary and nocturnal scavengers.
They are the largest carnivorous marsupial in the world.

calendar.name: termite
facts: Termite queens can live up to 50 years, making them among the longest-living insects.
Some termite mounds can be over 30 feet tall and contain millions of individuals.
Termites are more closely related to cockroaches than to ants.
They cultivate fungi in their nests as a food source.

calendar.name: tiger shark
facts: They are born with distinctive stripes that fade as they mature.
Tiger sharks are one of the few shark species that can tolerate freshwater.
They have unique, saw-like teeth that can cut through turtle shells.
Tiger sharks are called 'garbage cans of the sea' because they'll eat almost anything.

calendar.name: toad
facts: Toads have dry, warty skin, while frogs have smooth, moist skin.
Toads are more terrestrial than frogs and are often found far from water.
Some toads, like the cane toad, have become invasive species in certain regions.
They secrete toxins from their skin to deter predators, which can be harmful if ingested.

calendar.name: topi
facts: They have a unique 'pronking' behavior where they leap stiff-legged when alarmed.
They have specialized scent glands that help them mark their territory.
Topis are fast antelopes that can reach speeds of up to 50 mph.
Male topis defend small territories where females come to mate.

calendar.name: trout
facts: Trout have excellent vision and can see in color.
They can detect vibrations in the water through their lateral line system.
Some trout species migrate between freshwater and saltwater during their life cycle.
They are indicators of clean water and are sensitive to pollution.

randomAnimals.name: puffin
facts: Puffins are excellent swimmers, using their wings to 'fly' underwater.
They can carry dozens of small fish crosswise in their beaks at once.
Puffins are seabirds with colorful beaks that brighten during mating season.
They nest in burrows on cliffs and return to the same site year after year.

randomAnimals.name: walrus
facts: Walruses use their tusks to haul themselves onto ice and to forage for food.
They are found in Arctic waters.
Walruses are large marine mammals known for their prominent tusks.
They are social animals and live in large herds.

randomAnimals.name: bee
facts: They communicate through a complex 'waggle dance' to share location of flowers.
A single bee will only produce 1/12th of a teaspoon of honey in her lifetime.
Bees have five eyes and can see ultraviolet patterns on flowers invisible to humans.
They maintain their hive temperature at exactly 95Â°F year-round.
